relation: Emergency buttons in case of mugging or whatever are peppered throughout the campus. The campus police do their job well and send out reports via text messages to students about any potential danger and suspects in the area, which tends to be rare.
Philadelphia is the fifth largest city in the U.S. There's going to be something to do with your friends if you're fine with walking a bit or taking the campus bus or paying for the subway.

The meal plans are adequate. They include meal swipes, which are redeemed for a buffet at the dining center, and dining dollars, which can be spent at the campus market. Students can pick whether they want more of one or the other or neither. The dining center's food can be bland at times, but there are plenty of choices with about half of them cycling through every day. The campus market acts like a mini convenience store with Subway, Chick-fil-A, and Currito. The variety is slightly disappointing, but it's very close to the dorms which makes it good enough for the convenience. Outside of the meal plans, there are plenty of good restaurants and food trucks around the area and throughout Philadelphia. Whether you want good burgers, pizza, cheesesteaks, deli, Chinese, Halal, or fish tacos, there's something out there for you if you're fine with opening up your wallet.

There are about seven or eight different dorms to choose from. Some are classic two-to-a-room kind of dorms, while others might have three or four in a suite-style room. Each has their own flavor, and there are enough dorms to give students a real choice in how much privacy or social interaction they want. The only notable downside in all of the dorms is that they are all a slightly long walk to the dining center (ten to twelve minutes), but they are very close to the campus market with some other food choices relatively close by as well.

Drexel runs on a quarterly semester system. During freshman and senior years, it's effectively a trisemester system since the summer term is just a long break, but if you choose to do a co-op, sophomores and juniors work through summer with either more courses or their co-op work. The quick pace of the school also makes the courses faster and denser than some other colleges. It's not uncommon to see all of your project deadlines and exams on the same day or week.

Don't slack off after the first week or so. The work picks up pace fast with midterms taking place as quick as the fourth or fifth week. Make connections with your professors and go to some of your major's meet-and-greets. There are a lot of different courses to choose from, so it's nice to get to see which professors you like and what courses might be useful or interesting to you.

Drexel University is a great school for anyone looking to earn a head start in real world experience and building connections for a career. The co-op plans provide the perfect opportunity to learn the ins-and-outs of what's in store after college and is also good for anyone who isn't sure of what they want to be and wants to test out some work both in and out of the country. The work is hard and fast, but it pays--mostly literally.
